section.title: Registering &rhla; with &rmt;
section.para: Use this procedure to register &rhel; &productnumber; as a client of &rmt;.

important.para: &productname; only supports the latest minor version of &rhla; &productnumber;.

listitem.para: The &rmt; server is running rmt-server version 2.10 or later.
The &productname; &productnumber; repositories are available on the &rmt; server.
The system you want to register can access the &rmt; server.
You have a &productname; subscription activated in the &scc;.
You have removed the system from any &rh; subscription services it was registered to.

step.para: On the &rhla; system, download the rmt-client-setup-res script:
The option --remote-name (or -O) writes the output to a local file with the same name as the remote file.
Run the rmt-client-setup-res script with the URL of the &rmt; server as a parameter:

The script installs &suseconnect; and its dependencies, and replaces the existing release package with the &productname; release package. It then downloads and runs the rmt-client-setup script, which performs the following tasks:

listitem.para: Imports the keys with gpg --import and rpm --import.
Downloads the CA certificate from https://RMT_SERVER/rmt.crt.
Imports the CA certificate to the trust store.

step.para: You should see Successfully registered system.
You should see the following output:
If your subscription includes the &ha; extension, activate it with this command:

tip.para: To check whether the extension is available, run &suseconnect; --list-extensions.

step.para: The default repositories &reponameshort;-&productnumber;-Updates, &reponameshort;-AS-&productnumber;-Updates and &reponameshort;-CB-&productnumber;-Updates should be enabled. If you activated the &ha; extension, &reponameshort;-&productnumber;-HA-Updates should also be enabled.

You will also see optional Source and Debug repositories with the status disabled. Be aware that these repositories are listed even if they are not mirrored on the &rmt; server. You can check the mirrored repositories by browsing the directory listing at https://RMT_SERVER/repo/SUSE/Updates/ or by logging in to the &rmt; server and running rmt-cli repos list.
If you need the Source or Debug repositories, enable them using their repo id. You can enable multiple repositories at once:
Run the update command to make sure there are no errors:

section.para: You can now keep your system up to date from repositories provided by &productname;.
